dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This tool automates some of the steps in a geologic names review as required by USGS publication policy. It searches within a supplied list of map units for names and usages found in the U.S. Geologic Names Lexicon (Geolex) and provides a report template in spreadsheet form for the author and reviewer to use during the review process. The input is a GeMS-compliant DescriptionOfMapUnits (DMU) table and a list of U.S. state abbreviations within which the DMU is relevant. The tool reports the Geolex names found within the map unit name, the usages associated with those names, and whether or not the author's choice of geographic extent matches that found in Geolex. Comparisons of age and status (formal vs informal) are not at this time considered.

SAVE YOUR WORK BEFORE RUNNING THIS TOOL. It may cause ArcMap to crash.

tool.name: GeologicNamesCheck

param.name: DMU_Table
param.dialogReference: Choose a GeMS-compliant DescriptionOfMapUnits table. Must contain the fields HierarchyKey, MapUnit, Fullname, and Age, but they may be in any order, need not be CamelCase, and there are no spceial constraints on how the values are formatted. Values in Name are searched for Geolex names. If no Geolex name is found, Fullname is searched as well.
param.pythonReference:
For command line use, provide the full path to the table or, if being run from the same directory as the file, just the name.

Note that tables inside geodatabases or Excel files are specified by adding the table name after the file name separated by a path delimiter, eg. "C:\projects\JacksonQuad\Jackson.gdb\DescriptionOfMapUnits" or "C:\projects\JacksonQuad\Jackson.xlsx\DMU$"

param.name: States_extent
param.dialogReference:
Provide one or more (comma separated) state or territory abbreviations. Examples are:

  • WA

  • WA,OR

See https://pe.usps.com/text/pub28/28apb.htm for official USPS abbreviations.
param.pythonReference: For command line, provide one or more state or territory abbreviations separated by commas, eg., WA,OR,ID. Use no spaces unless entire list is enclosed in double quotes.

param.name: open_report_when_completed_
param.dialogReference: Should the Excel report file be opened when the script has finished running? Default is True. Check box off to disable.
param.pythonReference: For command line, state True or False. Default is True. Optional argument.

tool.usage:
This tool was written in Python 3.6 using standard libraries that are part of the ArcGIS Pro 2.4 anaconda distribution. It can be run with the parameter form from inside ArcGIS Pro or from the command line. The arguments, in both cases, are a DescriptionOfMapUnits table (DMU) and one or more state abbreviations. The DMU may be any table format recognized by ArcGIS Pro, including .csv and .xlsx files (but not .xls files). The table must contain the fields HierarchyKey, MapUnit, Fullname, and Age, but they may be in any order, need not be CamelCase, and there are no constraints on how the values are formatted. For instance, HierarchyKey is necessary for sorting the results in the author's intended order for easier review of map units that are stratigraphically adjacent or may participate in some kind of rank relationship, but it can be a so-called materialized path (eg., 02-01-04) or just a series of numbers.

The script sends queries to an API endpoint; internet access is required.
